thread.title: 'Creativity a team sport,' says Jobs biographer
thread.title_full: 'Creativity a team sport,' says Jobs biographer

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: 'Creativity a team sport,' says Jobs biographer
text:
A best-selling author of books about innovation told a Rochester audience Saturday that the key ingredients for innovation are combining technology with the humanities, along with a heavy dose of creativity and collaboration. "Creativity is a team sport," said Walter Isaacson in his keynote address for the University of Rochester's Meliora Weekend, which is an annual alumni reunion and homecoming.
Isaacson, who is president of the Aspen Institute, a research group based in Washington, D.C, spoke before an audience of about 1,400 at Kodak Hall in the Eastman Theatre.
His address drew from his two most recent books, The Innovators: How a Group of Hackers, Geniuses, and Geeks Created the Digital Revolution, and his biography, Steve Jobs .
Isaacson started his speech by calling Rochester a "hotbed of innovation again."
He said that, while the early years of the digital revolution were driven by technology, the future depends on a broader perspective.
"That's going to be the next wave of the digital revolution — those who connect the humanities with technology.
Steve Jobs, noted Isaacson, thought of himself as a humanities person who liked electronics.
The two inventions behind the technological changes of recent decades are the computer and Internet.
Both involved collaborative efforts. The same, added Isaacson, could be said about how Bell Labs developed the transistor — drawing from researchers with different expertise.
Isaacson previously served as a political correspondent and later editor of Time magazine. He then became chairman and CEO of CNN before moving on to the Aspen Institute in 2003.
His other books include biographies of Benjamin Franklin and Albert Einstein. He is now working on a biography of Leonardo da Vinci.
Franklin, said Isaacson, recognized the importance of hearing diverse voices, which prompted him to form a club of shopkeepers in Philadelphia.
Einstein was unusual in that he made his discoveries all by himself.
In speaking about the importance of humility, Isaacson said what a person contributes is much more important than trying to get credit for joint efforts. "It is not what you take from the river, it's what you put in," said Isaacson.
After his address, Isaacson answered questions posed by UR President Joel Seligman, who asked about the importance of individual genius.
Isaacson responded that while genius is important, the development and implementation of ideas is needed as well.
"You obviously need both," said Isaacson. "Vision without execution is just hallucination."
Isaacson also said that the high-tech nature of research today, such as in biotechnology, necessitates collaboration in a controlled environment.
"You don't want to try this in your dorm room," he noted.
When Seligman asked whether technology might stand in the way of human interactions, Isaacson told of the limitations of a computer and reminded Seligman that when they were growing up, households were glued to the TV.
"Interactive technology is so much better than the passive consumption that happened in the television age," he said.
The event ended with Isaacson telling of the importance of federal funding for research at universities, which are fertile grounds for innovation.
"We shouldn't deny our seed corn," said Isaacson.
JGOODMAN@Gannett.com.
